questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of events that occur during necrosis?

1) Cell swelling

2) Karyolysis

3) Karyorrhexis

4) Pyknosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1,4,3,2

The sequence of events in necrosis is: cellular swelling → pyknosis  →karyorrhexis  → karyolysis

Necrosis is defined as the spectrum of morphological changes that follow cell death due to the progressive degradative action of enzymes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady with a history of long-standing goitre presented with a solitary thyroid nodule. Histopathological examination of the thyroid mass shows nests of polygonal cells and pink eosinophilic extracellular material. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Medullary carcinoma

The presence of nests of polygonal cells and pink eosinophilic extracellular material (amyloid stroma) on histopathological examination, makes medullary carcinoma of the thyroid the most likely diagnosis

questions.text: What is the inheritance pattern of a syndrome associated with ovarian fibroma, ascites, and pleural effusion that resolves after tumor removal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

No inheritance pattern 

The clinical vignette describes Meig’s syndrome, it is an acquired disorder without genetic association.

questions.text: Which drug is used for maintenance therapy in opium addiction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Buprenorphine The drug used among the following options for maintenance therapy in opium addiction is buprenorphine.

Buprenorphine is a partial agonist at the mu opioid receptor and an antagonist at the kappa receptor.Hence it is used in opioid de-addiction

choices.text: Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb
Water outflow in thin descending limb
Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb
Flow of tubular fluid from PCT to DCT

questions.text: All of the following are components responsible for the countercurrent mechanism in the kidney except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Thin ascending limb is not a component of the countercurrent mechanism. The loop of Henle function as countercurrent multipliers and vasa recta as countercurrent exchangers.

questions.text: The drug 'X' is a GHRH analogue that is FDA-approved for the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy and not used for Growth hormone deficiency. Identify the drug ‘X’.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tesamorelin Tesamorelin is approved for use in HIV-associated lipodystrophy but not for GH deficiency. It is a synthetic N- terminal modified form of human GHRH. It does not get degraded by dipeptidyl peptidase 4 and therefore has a longer duration of action.

Tesamorelin is a medication used to reduce excess abdominal fat (visceral adiposity) in people with HIV who have lipodystrophy, a condition causing abnormal fat distribution. It is a synthetic growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) analogue that increases the body's natural production of growth hormone, which helps to reduce visceral fat.

questions.text: What formula is the dosing rate of a drug based on?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The formula for drug dosing rate is clearance x plasma concentration.

The equation for dose rate given here based on steady-state concentration. When a drug is given repeatedly at short intervals it will accumulate in the body until the elimination of the drug matches its input. So steady-state concentration is the plasma concentration at which the drug elimination and drug input balance each other.

questions.text: Aschoff bodies in rheumatic heart disease show all of the following features except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Aschoff bodies contain plump macrophages called anitschkow cells, T lymphocytes and ocassional plasma cells and foci of fibrinoid necrosis. It does not contain bacterial colonies

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. He was recently diagnosed with diabetes mellitus. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly. His liver microscopy on Prussian blue staining is given below. What is the mode of inheritance of his disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The given scenario is suggestive of hereditary hemochromatosis. It is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder that involves the HFE gene. Hemochromatosis is characterized by excessive iron accumulation that results in tissue damage. It consists of a triad of: Micronodular cirrhosis, Bronzing of the skin, Diabetes mellitus

questions.text: Marked cellular appendages are not found in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The marked cellular appendages in the above image is Cilia. Oviduct - Ciliated columnar epithelium. Ependyma - Ciliated cuboidal to columnar epithelium. Bronchi - Pseudo-stratified Ciliated columnar epithelium. Vasdeferens - Columnar epithelium with Sterocilia

questions.text: All of the following inhibit cytochrome oxidase except ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The four gases, nitric oxide (NO), carbon monoxide (CO), hydrogen sulfide (H(2)S) and hydrogen cyanide (HCN) all readily inhibit oxygen consumption by mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase along with cyanide. This inhibition is responsible for much of their toxicity when they are applied externally to the body.

questions.text: In von Willebrand disease, what does vWF primarily bind to aid platelet adhesion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Gp1b/IX The factor that von Willebrand factor (vWF) binds to is Gp1b/IX. Platelet adhesion is mediated by interactions between the platelet surface receptor glycoprotein GpIb/IX and vWF in the subendothelial matrix. Endothelial injury exposes vWF and causes the adhesion of platelets by the Gplb receptor.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles will be paralyzed if there is an injury to the nucleus underlying the marked structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lateral rectus The image shows the floor of the fourth ventricle, and the facial colliculus is marked. The abducens nucleus lies underneath the facial colliculus. Injury to the abducens nucleus will lead to paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle.

questions.text: A 35-year-old chronic hypertensive woman visits the outpatient department for pre-conceptional counseling. Which of the following anti-hypertensives should she discontinue?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors should be discontinued in pregnancy as they can cause hypoplasia of organs, growth retardation, and fetal loss. ACE inhibitors cause reduced perfusion and oligohydramnios leading to fetal growth retardation, calvarium maldevelopment, hypoplasia of lungs and kidneys, and limb contractures.

questions.text: A patient presented with an abscess on his back. Septic precautions were taken and the abscess was drained. On follow up, a healthy scar was visible. What is the type of collagen seen in the provisional matrix in this type of healing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The given scenario is an example of wound healing by secondary intention. The initial provisional matrix in this type of healing is composed of type III collagen, fibrin, and plasma fibronectin. It is later replaced by a matrix composed primarily of type I collagen. This type of healing occurs when cell or tissue loss is more extensive, such as in large wounds, abscesses, ulceration, and ischemic necrosis in parenchymal organs. The repair process involves a combination of regeneration and scarring.

questions.text: A newborn presented to the NICU with respiratory distress and meconium discharge from the umbilicus. The condition occurs due to the patency of which structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The presence of meconium discharge at the umbilicus is suggestive of vitelline fistula, which occurs due to patent vitelline duct, which connects the primitive gut to the yolk sac.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female has undergone mastectomy for Ca Breast. After mastectomy, patient is not able to extend, adduct and internally rotate the arm. Nerve supply to which of the following muscles is damaged:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Action of latissmus dorsi – extension, adduction and medial rotation of arm. Action of pectoralis major – flexion, adduction and medial rotation of arm

questions.text: A diabetic patient came with the complaint of pedal edema due to congestive heart failure and was prescribed a medication that is preferred in the setting of cardiac and renal failure. What is the drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

SGLT-2 inhibitor

In a diabetic patient with cardiac and renal failure, an SGLT-2 inhibitor like empagliflozin, canagliflozin, or dapagliflozin is used. These drugs block glucose reabsorption in the kidney, causing glycosuria, weight loss, blood pressure reduction, and offering cardiovascular and nephroprotective benefits.

questions.text: A patient on aspirin presented with occult blood in the stool. This is due to inhibition of which of the following by asprin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Aspirin causes inhibition of cyclooxygenase-1(COX-1) which would inhibit the formation of thromboxane A2. Thromboxane A2 is an inducer of platelet aggregation and is a potent vasoconstrictor. Hence inhibition of its formation is responsible for the bleeding complications of aspirin. Aspirin is a noncompetitive, irreversible inhibitor of the cyclooxygenase(COX) enzyme. It is a nonselective cox inhibitor and inhibits both COX-1 and Cox 2.

questions.text: ALK positivity is seen in which of the following neoplasms:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumour

ALK (anaplastic lymphoma kinase) positivity (translocation) is seen in Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor of lung.

questions.text: When is the best time to use TTC staining for clear visualization of myocardial necrosis after suspected infarction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

2-3 hours

TTC staining best identifies myocardial infarction within 2-3 hours. Infarcts less than 12 hours old are not visible grossly, but can be highlighted by TTC, which stains healthy tissue brick-red. Infarcted areas appear pale due to loss of enzyme activity.

questions.text: A child with loose stools for one day presented to your OPD. On examination, signs of dehydration were present and the child was given ORS. It facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

ORS facilitates glucose absorption through SGLT 1 (Sodium-dependent glucose co-transporter -1).

questions.text: Identify the mode of inheritance from the pedigree chart given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

The pedigree chart shows an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. Autosomal dominant conditions are manifested in the heterozygous state, hence at least one parent of an index case is usually affected. In this mode of inheritance, both males and females are affected and both can transmit the condition. When an affected person marries an unaffected one, every child has one in two chance of having the disease.

questions.text: Transport molecule for Fe2+ into the enterocytes is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Transport of Fe2+ into the enterocytes occurs via divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1), through an active transport process. Protein DMT-1 (Divalent Metal Transporter-1) is expressed on the apical surface of enterocytes in the initial part of the duodenum. DMT-1 is not specific to iron & transports other substances like zinc, copper, cobalt & manganese.

questions.text: Which of the following beta-adrenergic blockers are beneficial for patients with reduced ejection fraction and can reduce mortality in chronic heart failure without causing exacerbations over a few years?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bisoprolol

The beta-adrenergic blocker that is useful in patients with reduced ejection fraction and can reduce mortality in chronic heart failure without causing exacerbations over a few years is bisoprolol. Bisoprolol is preferred for use in patients having heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

questions.text: A hypertensive patient with chronic kidney disease was having frequent attacks of renal colic. Which of the following diuretics is used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hydrochlorothiazide For a hypertensive patient with chronic kidney disease experiencing frequent attacks of renal colic, hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic, is often used.

These medications augment the reabsorption of calcium in the proximal tubule, effectively reducing urinary calcium excretion and decreasing the risk of calcium crystal formation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man has surgery for a testicular mass. Histologic sections reveal the mass to be a testicular yolk sac tumor. Which of the substances listed below is most likely to be increased in this patient’s serum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tumors sometimes secrete specific substances that appear in the serum. These tumor markers can be used clinically for diagnosis, for staging, and for following patients after surgery to look for recurrences of the tumor. Two important tumor markers associated with testicular neoplasms are α-fetoprotein (AFP) and human chorionic gonadotropin–β (hCG-β).

Alpha foeto protein is elevated in case of yolk sac tumour

questions.text: A chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patient requires a step-up in therapy due to symptom persistence. Which PDE-4 inhibitor can you prescribe as an add-on drug to his treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Roflumilast

Roflumilast is a PDE-4 selective inhibitor approved for use in COPD. PDE-4 is the major isoform present in inflammatory cells and its inhibition results in higher anti-inflammatory effects

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in irreversible cell injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Large amorphous densities in mitochondria

Irreversible injury features large amorphous densities, vacuoles, and phospholipid deposits in mitochondria, indicating ATP loss. Severe damage involves calcium influx and flocculent densities, especially after reperfusion, leading to permanent cell death.

questions.text: Thiamine deficiency leads to lactic acidosis. Which enzyme action is inhibited in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) acts as a coenzyme for various enzymes. Active form of thiamine is Thiamine Pyrophosphate (TPP).

Thiamine is a crucial cofactor for enzymes involved in carbohydrate metabolism, specifically the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, which converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA for the Krebs cycle. When thiamine is deficient, pyruvate cannot be properly processed, and instead, it's converted to lactate by lactate dehydrogenase, leading to lactic acidosis.

questions.text: Which of the following passes between superior & middle constrictor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictor muscles, the stylopharyngeus muscle and the glossopharyngeal nerve pass through. Between the middle and inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscles, the internal laryngeal nerve and the superior laryngeal artery and vein pass through.

questions.text: Which of the following modes of activation is most commonly found in RAS proto-oncogenes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Point mutation

Point mutations of the RAS gene family constitute the most common type of abnormality involving proto- oncogenes in human tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is excreted in the urine of a patient with essential pentosuria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

L-xylulose

L-xylulose is excreted in the urine of a patient with essential pentosuria.

questions.text: Aldosterone secretion is maximally stimulated by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Hyperkalemia and activation of renin-angiotensin system are the most potent stimulators of aldosterone secretion.

questions.text: A 75-year-old female presented with urinary incontinence. She also has cognition decline and dementia. Which of the following drugs is useful for treating urinary incontinence?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tolterodine For managing urinary incontinence in a 75-year-old female with cognitive decline and dementia, tolterodine is useful.

Tolterodine being an anticholinergic which do not cross BBB,hence do not affect memory, can be used in patients having dementia

questions.text: The activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) is prolonged in the deficiency of all of the following coagulation factors except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) measures the clotting time of plasma via the intrinsic pathway. Factor VII is a part of the extrinsic pathway. Hence, aPTT is not prolonged in factor VII deficiency.

questions.text: From which period of embryogenesis does the liver become the chief site of hematopoiesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

3rd month 

From the 3rd month of embryogenesis, the liver becomes the chief site of hematopoiesis.

Development of hematopoietic tissues:

•	Yolk sac – blood cell progenitors first appear during the 3rd week

•	Liver – hematopoietic stem cells migrate to the liver during the 3rd month of embryogenesis

•	Bone marrow – hematopoiesis starts in bone marrow during the 4th month of intrauterine life and becomes the predominant site after birth

choices.text: Ttricuspid valve bulging into right atria

questions.text: In the Jugular Venous Pressure waveform what does the “a” wave correspond to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Atrial contraction

‘A’ wave of the JVP corresponds to atrial contraction.

questions.text: miRNA binds at which of the following regions of mRNA ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

miRNAs (microRNAs) are short non-coding RNAs that regulate gene expression posttranscriptionally. They generally bind to the 3'-UTR (untranslated region) of their target mRNAs and repress protein production by destabilizing the mRNA and translational silencing.

questions.text: cGMP is the second messenger of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Vasodilatory actions of NO are mediated by cGMP. NO is a hormone derived from the amino acid arginine. It activates guanylyl cyclases in vascular smooth muscle cells resulting in the conversion of cGTP to cGMP (2nd messenger). cGMP activates cGMP dependent protein kinase, which causes blood vessels to relax.

questions.text: Bulla ethmoidalis drains into which among the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Middle meatus

Bulla ethmoidalis -It is an ethmoidal cell situated behind the uncinate process. It forms posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris and drains to middle meatus.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl, who is an alleged victim of rape, was brought to you for examination. Upon evaluating the stains present on her clothes, the following findings were observed: the pH of the stain was 7.4, the Florence test was negative, and the Kastle-Meyer test was positive. Based on these findings, what is the likely type of specimen detected in the stain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Blood

A positive Kastle Meyer’s (phenolphthalein) test is suggestive of a bloodstain. This test is done by adding phenolphthalein reagent and hydrogen peroxide to the extracted stain sample. Pink or purple color indicates a positive test.

questions.text: A third-year medical student is on his first rotation in internal medicine. His attending physician points out that there are several tests that are used to diagnose syphilis. Which test is most specific for the detection of syphilis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

There are two classes of test used to detect the presence of an infection. The nontreponemal tests detect the presence of antibodies against lipids present on the organism. The nontreponemal tests include RPR and VDRL. Specific tests that detect antibodies against the organism itself, include TP-PA and FTA-ABS. Aerobic and anaerobic cultures are not specific tests used to identify syphilis.

questions.text: What is known as the change in the occurrence of a disease over very long periods of time?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Secular trend

A secular trend refers to the changes in the occurrence of a disease over long periods of time (decade).

questions.text: On the day of delivery, a newborn baby is undergoing a screening test for hearing. Which of the following tests is likely to be performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Otoacoustic emissions (OAE)

A newborn baby on the same day of delivery will undergo the Otoacoustic emissions (OAE) test as a screening test for hearing.

questions.text: A 33-year-old nurse suffered a needle stick injury. The patient used illicit intravenous drugs. One month later, the nurse develops jaundice. Which of the following findings would implicate hepatitis B as the etiology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The presence of hepatitis B surface antigen means  virus is present in the body, and in the context of the recent needle stick injury, this likely represents a hepatitis B infection. The presence of HBeAg is a marker of active disease and infectivity.

questions.text: A patient has undergone a high-resolution CT of the temporal bone which confirmed a diagnosis of semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome. Which of the following will not be affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Medial semicircular canal

The medial semicircular canal does not exist. The semicircular canals are part of the bony labyrinth. They house the semicircular ducts which are the end organs for angular momentum.

questions.text: As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, 2021, induction of MTP in a mentally ill or a rape victim is allowed until what age of gestation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

24 weeks

As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act, 2021, the induction of MTP in a mentally ill woman or a rape victim is allowed until 24 weeks

questions.text: When is breastfeeding week celebrated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

1st week of August

Breastfeeding week is celebrated in the 1st week of August.

questions.text: Identify the type of tympanoplasty shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Type 3 The columella tympanoplasty is type 3 as per the Wullstein’s classification of tympanoplasty. While performing this procedure, the diseased ear would have already lost the malleus and incus, and hence the graft is placed over the stapes superstructure. Therefore, it is also called myringostapediopexy.

questions.text: A woman In her second trimester comes to the PHC for her regular check-up. You give her advice regarding her nutritional requirement. How much should the increase be in her caloric intake per day?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

340 Kcal/day

The caloric intake per day should be increased to 340 Kcal/day for a woman in her second trimester.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most peripheral centre under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme organization structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Designated Microscopy Centre 

Among the options given, Designated Microscopy Centre is the most peripheral centre

questions.text: In a normal distribution, the mean value is 82 and SD is 1.5. Calculate the range of 2 SD.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

79 to 85

The range of 2 standard deviations for the given mean value is 79 to 85.

To determine the range within two standard deviations in a normal distribution, we use the formula; Range= Mean ±2 x Standard Deviation (SD)

questions.text: A 3-year-old is diagnosed with bacterial meningitis. Cerebrospinal fluid grows out gram-positive cocci in short chains and diplococci. This is most likely to be which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Streptococcus pneumoniae is responsible for 10–20 percent of meningitis cases in children ages 1 month to 15 years.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high-arched palate, and impaired hearing. Tympanogram is given as follows. What would be the most appropriate management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion The given clinical scenario along with type B tympanometry curve is suggestive of serous otitis media secondary to adenoid hypertrophy. Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion would be the most appropriate management.

questions.text: An individual experiences diarrhea after eating raw shellfish. What is the most probable cause of the problem?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a halophilic bacterium that causes acute gastroenteritis following ingestion of contaminated seafood such as raw fish or shellfish. After 12–24 hours, the patient develops nausea and vomiting, abdominal cramps, fever, and watery to bloody diarrhea. It is usually self-limited in 1–4 days, requiring only restoration of water and electrolytes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with complaints of constipation, abdominal cramps, and tingling in the extremities. His bloodwork shows a lead level of 50 µg/dL. What is the antidote preferred for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

DMSA

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lead poisoning. Calcium EDTA and DMSA (succimer) are the preferred antidotes for lead poisoning. In a patient highly exposed to lead, chelation with oral DMSA (succimer) is recommended.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy develops bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps. The bacteria isolated from the stool specimen fermented lactose and produced colorless colonies on sorbitol MacConkey agar. The most likely etiological agent in this case is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Shiga toxin-producing E.Coli

A boy with bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps, with bacteria fermenting lactose and forming clear colonies on sorbitol MacConkey agar, likely has Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC) 0157:H7 (EHEC). Unlike other E. coli, which produce pink colonies, STEC 0157:H7 does not ferment sorbitol, resulting in colorless colonies.

questions.text: The following instrument is useful in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Anterior rhinoscopy The above Instrument is a thudicum nasal speculum. It is used to part the ala so as to visualize the anterior part of the nasal cavity.

questions.text: Short incubation food poisoning, caused by ingestion of preformed enterotoxin, is caused by which bacteria listed below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Of the options given the best answer is S. aureus, as a result of enterotoxin production in food. None of the other strains listed produce enterotoxins that result in short-term gastroenteritis.

questions.text: A child is brought to the casualty with a history of dyspnea. His mother gives a history of foreign body aspiration. What is the first investigation to be done?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

X-ray

The first investigation in a child with suspicion of foreign body aspiration is Xray. Food items (nuts, seeds hard candy, gum, bones raw fruits, and vegetables) account for the majority of choking cases in children. The most common site of foreign body lodging is the bronchus. Foreign body aspiration into the airway has three stages: immediate symptoms of coughing and choking, an asymptomatic interval, and later complications such as fever, atelectasis, and pneumonia.

questions.text: Under the Integrated Disease Surveillance Project (IDSP), sentinel surveillance is conducted for which diseases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

HIV, Hepatitis B

Under the Integrated Disease Surveillance Project (IDSP), sentinel surveillance is conducted for HIV and Hepatitis B. The main purpose of the Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP) is to detect early warning signals of outbreaks.

questions.text: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 30 children in rural and 20 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Chi Square test

The most appropriate test of significance, in this case, is the chi-square test. It is used to compare qualitative data between 2 groups with independent measures.

choices.text: K1 antigen – neonatal meningitis caused by Escherichia coli

questions.text: Which of the following is mismatched?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Organisms requiring high salt concentrations are called halophilic. Usually, this refers to microorganisms that are capable of living or surviving in an ocean or saltwater area. Vibrios are especially well known for this ability. Salmonella typhi (typhoid fever) multiply in intestinal lymphoid tissue and are excreted in stools. They are hardy survivors in water sources, but they do not survive in halophilic conditions as well as Vibrios.

questions.text: A man is convicted for the offense of rape. Which section of the BNS lays down punishment for the same?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Section 64 (IPC 376)

Section 64 of the BNS (IPC 376) lays down the punishment for the offense of rape. Section 64 (1) of the BNS outlines the punishment for rape and section 64 (2) outlines the punishment for rape in custody/rape by a person in a position of authority or trust

questions.text: A woman gave birth to a child 8 months after the death of her husband. The in-laws claim that the child is not their son, however, the DNA testing confirms the paternity. The child is known as
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Posthumous child

The child delivered after the death of the biological father, or a child delivered after the death of the biological mother, usually when delivered by a cesarean section is a posthumous child.

choices.text: Plan surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery
Bed rest and avoiding strenuous activity

questions.text: A 33-year-old male met with a road traffic accident. There is persistent watery discharge mixed with blood from his nose for 3 days which cannot be sniffed back. Which of the following should not be done in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Plan surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery

In the given scenario of a male presenting with watery nasal discharge mixed with blood that cannot be sniffed back following a road traffic accident is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea. Surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery should not be done in this patient.

questions.text: A Tzanck smear prepared from a vesicle sample revealed multinucleated giant cells. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Herpes Simplex Virus 

Tzanck cells or multinucleated giant cells are indicative of Herpes Simplex virus. In genital herpes, clusters of vesicles are seen on an erythematous base along with painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy and Tzanck cells or multinucleated giant cells are seen in this condition.

choices.text: Years of life lost due to premature death

questions.text: What is the Sullivan’s index?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Life expectancy free from disability

It is also called disability-free life expectancy (DFLE) and active life expectancy.It is the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability, if current pattern of mortality and disability continue to apply.

questions.text: The treatment of paucibacillary leprosy consists of MDT (which comprises rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine). The latest recommended regimen is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

3 drug therapy for 6 months

The latest recommendation is 3 drug therapy for 6 months to treat paucibacillary (PB) leprosy by WHO. The regimen consists of rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine. Meanwhile, multibacillary (MB) leprosy is treated using the same 3 drugs for a duration of 12 months. While the NLEP guidelines earlier mentioned a 2-drug MDT for PB leprosy, the National Strategic Plan and Roadmap for Leprosy (2023- 2027) now recommends a uniform MDT of 3 drugs for both PB and MB leprosy.

questions.text: The dose of iodine for lactating women in India according to the recommended dietary allowance is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

280 µg/day

According to the National Institute of Nutrition (NIN) 2020 guidelines, the recommended dietary allowance (RDA) for dietary iodine in lactating women in India is 280 µg/day.

questions.text:
A patient's laboratory result is positive for typhoid and Widal test findings are given below. What is the most appropriate stage of this disease?

O Ag > 1:20

H Ag > 1:380

A Ag > 1:20

B Ag > 1:20
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Reconvalescence

In this patient with suspected typhoid, the Widal test has shown only the H antigen being positive, the condition is most likely the reconvalescence phase of Typhoid.

questions.text: Which artery is most commonly affected in bleeding from the nose?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sphenopalatine artery

The most commonly affected artery in bleeding from the nose is the sphenopalatine artery. It is called the artery of epistaxis because of the same.

questions.text: An Social Health Activist (USHA) workers are proposed to work for a population of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

1000-2500

USHA will cover a population of 1000 to 2500.She must be a woman who resides in the slum, preferably of age 25 to 45. This was a provision given by the National Urban Health Mission which was passed by the cabinet in 2013.

choices.text: Provide LPG connections to families below poverty line
Provide LED bulbs in every household

questions.text: Which of the following is the objective of the Ujjawala Scheme?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Prevent human trafficking

The Ujjawala Scheme is for the prevention of trafficking and for the rescue, rehabilitation, and reintegration of victims of trafficking for commercial sexual exploitation

questions.text: Which of the following is not transmitted by lice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Q fever

Q fever is not transmitted by lice. It is spread by the inhalation of contaminated aerosols containing Coxiella burnetti.

questions.text: A child was eating a custard apple when a seed suddenly became lodged in the throat, causing coughing and respiratory distress. On palpation, a knob-like structure was felt, and auscultation revealed an audible thud. What is the likely location of the obstruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Trachea

A history of cough, respiratory distress, a palpable knob and on auscultation, an audible thud in a child suggests a foreign body lodged in the trachea.

questions.text: For the diagnosis of Rickettsia, an antigen of Proteus is used. What is this type of antigen called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Heterophile antigen

In the diagnosis of Rickettsia infections, the heterophile antigen of Proteus is utilized in the Weil-Felix test, which is a form of heterophile agglutination reaction.

questions.text: A total of 60 patients were diagnosed with COVID-19, out of which 12 cases of deaths were reported. Calculate the case fatality rate.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

20%

In this scenario, among 60 diagnosed COVID-19 patients, 12 deaths were recorded, resulting in a case fatality rate of 20%.

The case fatality rate is determined using the formula: (Number of deaths from a specific disease / Total number of cases of the same disease) x 100. Applying this formula: (12 deaths / 60 cases) x 100 = 20%.

questions.text: The sustainable development goals adopted in 2015 aim to reduce the under 5 mortality rate to as low as per 1000 live births by the year 2030.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

25

The sustainable development goals adopted in 2015 aim to reduce the under 5 mortality to as low as 25 per 1000 live births by the year 2030.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient presented with Sudden painless loss of vision. She has been a known diabetic for 12 years. Ophthalmoscopy shows evidence of loss of fundal features, floating debris and a dark red glow. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Vitreous haemorrhage This patient with long-standing diabetes with sudden, painless vision loss, floating debris and a dark red glow on fundoscopic examination is most likely suffering from vitreous haemorrhage.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the casualty with a sudden loss of vision and painful ocular movements. On examination, the eye is white and there are no obvious signs on ophthalmoscopy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Retrobulbar neuritis

The given clinical scenario of a sudden painful loss of vision in the absence of fundoscopic changes is suggestive of retrobulbar neuritis

questions.text: What is the most common mutation identified in patients with autosomal dominant hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ankyrin Mutations of the gene coding for ankyrin are the most common cause of autosomal dominant hereditary spherocytosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents with pain and stiffness in the shoulders and hips, especially in the morning. Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Polymyalgia rheumatica is characterized by pain and stiffness in the shoulders and hips, often worse in the morning, and elevated ESR.

questions.text: Identify the visual field defect in the given image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Homonymous hemianopia

The visual field defect in the given image is the right homonymous hemianopia. Right homonymous hemianopia, marked by loss of vision in the right half of the visual field of both eyes, indicates a lesion in the left optic tract. This occurs because the optic tract transmits visual information from the left nasal retina and right temporal retina, and disruption leads to right-sided visual field loss.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient with class II pulmonary hypertension presents with a negative vasoreactivity test. Which of the following is used in the next step of management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ambrisentan In a patient with class II pulmonary hypertension (low risk) with a negative vasoreactivity test, the next best step of management is to start on ambrisentan (endothelin receptor antagonist).

questions.text: A 24-year-old man develops seizures following an emergent splenectomy after a car accident. His serum sodium level is initially 116 mEq/L and is corrected to 120 mEq/L over the next 3 hours with hypertonic saline. Which of the following factors most likely led to his hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

In the postoperative state or in situations where the patient is in pain, the serum vasopressin level may rise, leading to inappropriate retention of free water, which leads to dilution of the serum. Concomitant administration of hypotonic fluids may exacerbate the situation.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to your office for her annual physical examination. On examination, you note neck fullness. When you palpate her thyroid, it is enlarged, smooth, rubbery, and nontender. The patient is asymptomatic. You send her for thyroid function testing: her T4 , free T4 , and T3 are normal, but her TSH is slightly elevated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hashimoto thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism with goiter. It is most commonly found in middle-aged women, although it can be seen in all age groups. Patients can present with a rubbery, nontender goiter that may have “scalloped” borders.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman, who was on treatment for sinusitis presents with right eye pain associated with high-grade fever, chills, and headache. Examination of the right eye reveals periorbital edema, ptosis, sluggish pupillary response, and lateral rectus palsy. Bilateral proptosis and papilledema are also present. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cavernous sinus thrombosis The given clinical scenario of a patient with sinusitis presenting with fever, bilateral proptosis, eye pain, ptosis, sluggish pupillary reaction, lateral rectus palsy, and papilloedema is pointing towards the diagnosis of cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Cranial nerve palsies in case of cavernous sinus thrombosis:-
CN III (oculomotor) → ptosis, eye movement restriction

CN IV (trochlear) → vertical diplopia

CN V1 and V2 (trigeminal branches) → facial pain or numbness in forehead, cheek

CN VI (abducens) → most commonly affected → inability to abduct eye (lateral rectus palsy)

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman infected with HIV is noted to have a CD4 count of 180 cells/mm3. Which of the following is recommended as a useful prophylactic agent in this patient at this point?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole When the CD4 count falls to less than 200 cells/mm3, trimethoprim sulfamethoxazole (Bactrim) prophylaxis is generally initiated to prevent PCP. Prophylaxis against Mycobacterium avium–intracellulare complex usually is started when the CD4 count is less than 50 cells/mm3, and toxoplasmosis prophylaxis usually is started when the CD4 count is less than 100 cells/mm3.

questions.text: A 59-year-old male patient came to OPD with the complaints of glare during night drives. He had undergone cataract surgery 1 year back. The best-corrected visual acuity is RE = 6/12 and LE = 6/9. No improvement with pinhole. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Posterior capsular opacification

The given clinical picture of a post cataract surgery patient coming with symptoms of glare and reduced visual acuity which doesn’t improve on pinhole testing is suggestive of posterior capsular opacification (PCO).

questions.text: A patient has presented for a routine eye evaluation. You have checked his visual acuity using Snellen’s chart and found it to be 6/6. What is the minimum angle of resolution?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

5 minutes of arc The angle subtended for a patient with 6/6 vision is 5 minutes of arc. Visual acuity is a measure of the spatial resolution of the eye or an estimation of its ability to discriminate between two points.

The minimum angle of resolution (MAR) on a Snellen chart is the smallest angular size a person can discern, typically expressed in minutes of arc. For a person with normal vision (20/20 or 6/6), this is 1 minute of arc (60 seconds of arc). This means they can distinguish two objects if they subtend an angle of at least 1 minute at the eye.
It has to be multiplied by 5.Hence, answer will be 5 minutes of arc.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with shortness of breath. He is a known case of COPD and has had similar episodes in the past, which required hospitalization. The classification according to GOLD’s criteria was moderate COPD. What are the likely PFT values of the patient considering this classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 50% to 80% 

The expected pulmonary function test (PFT) values in this patient are FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 50% to 80%.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a feature of joint pain seen in patients with rheumatic fever?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Symmetric involvement

In cases of acute rheumatic fever, joint pain typically does not affect both sides equally. Instead, it is characterized by a migratory pattern, where the discomfort shifts from one large joint to another within a few hours. The joints most often involved are large joints such as the knees, ankles, hips, and elbows. This form of arthritis is notably asymmetric, meaning one side is affected more than the other. Furthermore, these joint symptoms tend to respond very well to treatment with salicylates.Thus, symmetric joint involvement is not a feature of rheumatic fever-related arthritis.

questions.text: The following image depicts a particular type of cataract. What history should be elicited from the patient to come to a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Blunt trauma

The above image characteristically depicts a rosette cataract. It typically follows closed globe injuries (blunt trauma), and hence is also known as the concussion cataract.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is noted to have congestive heart failure and states that he is comfortable at rest but becomes dyspneic even with walking to bathroom. On echocardiography, he is noted to have an ejection fraction of 47%. Which of the following is the more accurate description of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Diastolic dysfunction 

When the ejection fraction exceeds 40%, there is likely diastolic dysfunction, with stiff ventricles. The stiff thickened ventricles do not accept blood very readily. This patient has symptoms with mild exertion which are indicative of functional class III. The worst class is level IV, manifested as symptoms at rest or with minimal exertion. ACE inhibitors are important agents in patients with diastolic dysfunction

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old woman who has lacy lesions in her mouth and genital area, while her proximal nail fold has extended onto the nail bed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Lichen planus

Lichen Planus is an autoimmune disorder and it is mediated by T cells . It affects the basement membrane zone of the cell. It is a condition of the skin, hair, nails, mouth and genitals. On skin, lichen planus often appears as purple, itchy, flat bumps that develop over several weeks.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with ruptured vesicles and bullae on the skin and erosions in the mucous membrane. HPE of the skin biopsy revealed a row of tombstones. Antibodies against which of the following structures are most commonly present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The above clinical features and HPE findings in this patient suggest the diagnosis of Pemphigus vulgaris (PV), which most commonly has antibodies against Desmoglein 3.

questions.text: Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase score is decreased in patients with all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Polycythemia vera

Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is increased in polycythemia vera and leukemoid reactions.

questions.text: A patient with a history of a backache for 10 days, has now presented with sudden onset difficulty in micturition and defaecation. There was no history of cough or fever previously. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cauda Equina Syndrome This is a case of cauda equina syndrome. It signifies an injury of multiple lumbosacral nerve roots within the spinal canal distal to the termination of the spinal cord at L1-L2. It is commonly due to a ruptured lumbosacral intervertebral disk, lumbosacral spine fracture, hematoma within the spinal canal, compressive tumor, or other mass lesions.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with progressive deterioration of vision. On examination, the pupillary reaction is sluggish and the IOP is elevated. Fundoscopy shows a large and deep cup and the visual field reveals paracentral scotoma. What is the first line of treatment for this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Timolol

The given clinical scenario of deterioration of vision, sluggish pupils, elevated IOP and paracentral scotoma is suggestive of primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG). Timolol is one of the first-line agents used in the treatment of primary open- angle glaucoma.

questions.text: Dietary folates are absorbed from which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Duodenum

Dietary folates are absorbed from the duodenum and jejunum in the form of monoglutamates. Vitamin B12 absorption takes place in the terminal ileum

questions.text: A patient after RTA underwent ileal resection. He presents with fatigue, which of the following will not be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Microcytic hypochromic anemia

After complete ileal resection, a patient with fatigue is unlikely to have microcytic anemia. In contrast, the patient is likely to have macrocytic anemia due to B12 deficiency.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with complaints of headache and blurring of vision. On examination, there was a difference in visual acuity. In the right eye, it was (+5D) and in the left, it was (+1D). After the best possible correction for vision, visual acuity in the right eye is 6/18 and in the left is 6/24. On fundoscopy, no pathology could be appreciated. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Anisometric Amblyopia

The most probable diagnosis from the given scenario is Anisometric Amblyopia. A young child with a difference of vision in both eyes that is not improved after correction for refractive error supports the diagnosis. Due to the difference in refractive power, vision in one eye gets suppressed which is not apparent on examination.

choices.text: Normal PR and prolonged RR interval
Prolonged PR and normal RR interval
Short PR and normal RR interval

questions.text: What is correct about first-degree heart block?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prolonged PR and normal RR interval

The correct statement about the first-degree heart block is the ECG shows prolonged PR and normal RR interval.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cutaneous marker of underlying internal malignancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Erythema chronicum migrans is not typically a marker of internal malignancy; it is the characteristic rash associated with early Lyme disease , which is caused by the tick-borne bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi.

questions.text: During your rural service, a patient arrives at the OPD with hypopigmented lesions on his trunk and back. A Wood’s lamp examination of the lesions shows yellow fluorescence, and scales become prominent when the lesion is scratched with nails. Which of the following organisms causes this infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

The condition described is Pityriasis Versicolor, also known as Tinea Versicolor. The term "tinea" is a misnomer, as this infection is caused by the Malassezia species (including M. globosa, M.sympodialis, and M. furfur), not by dermatophytes like Microsporum or Trichophyton.

questions.text: A young lady presents with recent-onset palpitations and dizziness. Her ECG shows absent P waves and an irregularly irregular RR interval. Her pulse rate is 140 bpm and BP is 80/60 mmHg. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Synchronized cardioversion

In the given clinical scenario, the patient presenting with recent-onset palpitations and dizziness with ECG showing irregularly irregular rhythm with absent p waves, is suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Since the patient is hemodynamically compromised (hypotension), synchronized cardioversion is the most appropriate management.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient was brought to the emergency due to complaints of palpitations and breathing difficulty. Comment on his ECG.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ventricular bigeminy

The above ECG shows a pattern of premature ventricular contractions, one premature beat after one normal beat. This is seen in ventricular bigeminy. Premature ventricular contractions/beats (PVC) are single ventricular beats that occur earlier than the next normal supraventricular beat.

questions.text: A patient present with a unilateral throbbing headache in the temporal region and light sensitivity associated with photophobia, nausea and vomiting. She reports that each episode lasts for a maximum of 24 hours, which was relieved by giving triptans. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Migraine

The clinical picture of throbbing unilateral headache, light sensitivity associated with photophobia, nausea and vomiting and responsiveness to triptans indicates a diagnosis of migraine.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with joint pain and swelling, especially in the wrists and knees. She has a history of urethritis. What serologic marker is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

HLA-B27 

Joint pain, urethritis, and a strong association with HLA-B27 are characteristic of reactive arthritis (formerly known as Reiter’s syndrome).

questions.text: A 6-month-old child is noted to have muscle weakness. Vitals Pulse: 80/min, BP 70/50 mm Hg. The workup shows metabolic alkalosis with hypokalaemia and hypomagnesemia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Gitelman syndrome

The given clinical scenario of a 6-month-old child presenting with muscle weakness with a pulse of 80/min and BP 70/50 mm Hg (hypotension) with metabolic alkalosis, hypokalaemia and hypomagnesemia is suggestive of Gitelman syndrome

questions.text: A 45-year-old man had severe hypothyroidism. His arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows very low pO2 and high pCO2 levels. Which of the following types of respiratory failure is likely to be present in him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Type 2 

The clinical scenario of severe hypothyroidism with hypoxemia and hypercapnia is suggestive of type 2 respiratory failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common inherited bleeding disorder?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Von Willebrand disease Von Willebrand disease (vWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder. VWD occurs due to deficient or abnormal von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is synthesized by endothelial cells and megakaryocytes (gene located on chromosome 12p). It is then stored in endothelial storage vesicles, Weibel- Palade bodies. Metalloprotease ADAMTS13 cleaves ultra- large multimers of VWF which are responsible for platelet adhesion.

questions.text: A truck driver reports multiple painful genital ulcers on his scrotum following unprotected sexual intercourse, accompanied by painful lymph nodes. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Chancroid is characterized by painful genital ulcers and swollen, painful lymph nodes (inguinal lymphadenopathy). The ulcers are typically soft, with irregular edges. It is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi.

questions.text: In patients with infective endocarditis, the vegetations are most commonly present on:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mitral valve

The mitral valve is the most common valve affected in infective endocarditis. Infective endocarditis is the infection of the endocardial layer of the heart. It may involve the endocardial layer over the heart valves, mural endocardium, or septum. However, it can also affect intracardiac devices

choices.text: SBP >130 mm Hg and DBP > 80 mm Hg

questions.text: Which of the factors would suggest a risk for a patient with TIA developing stroke in the future according to ABCD2 scoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Diabetes

According to the ABCD2 scoring system, which is commonly used to assess the short-term risk of stroke following a transient ischemic attack (TIA), diabetes would suggest a higher risk factor.

questions.text: All of the following are associated with autonomic neuropathies, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hyperthyroidism

In hyperthyroidism, excessive thyroxine causes sympathetic autonomic overactivity, not neuropathy. Hypothyroidism can be associated with peripheral neuropathy, most typically carpal tunnel syndrome. Treatment is the correction of hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with muscle weakness and difficulty swallowing. EMG reveals fibrillation potentials and positive sharp waves. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Muscle weakness, difficulty swallowing, and EMG findings of fibrillation potentials and positive sharp waves are indicative of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

questions.text: A neonate is brought with complaints of photophobia and watering. Clinical examination shows normal tear passages and clear but large cornea. Investigation reveals Haab’s striae seen in the eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Buphthalmos

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of buphthalmos. Haab’s striae are horizontal/circumferential breaks in Descemet’s membrane seen in buphthalmos. Buphthalmos (Bull-like eyes) is an enlargement of the eyeball seen in true congenital and infantile glaucoma, usually when the disease onset is before 3 years.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of revised trauma score (RTS)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pulse rate is NOT a part of revised trauma score. The Revised Trauma Score is made up of three categories: Glasgow Coma Scale, systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate

choices.text: Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube
Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib
Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury

questions.text: An intern placed an intercostal drainage tube in a patient. Which of the following steps is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

An intercostal tube (ICD) is placed along the upper border of the lower rib, in order to prevent damage to the neurovascular bundle. An ICD connected to an underwater seal is central to the management of chest disease.

choices.text: Pneumothorax on left side due to PPV

questions.text: What is the most likely cause when a patient under general anaesthesia develops left lung collapse after intubation, with breath sounds heard only on the right side during auscultation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Right endobronchial intubation

The most likely cause of left lung collapse after intubation, with breath sounds heard only on the right side, is endobronchial intubation of the right main bronchus.

questions.text: Heberden’s nodes are seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Distal Interphalangeal Joint (DIP)

Heberden nodes are the knobbly appearance of DIP. They are formed due to the formation of osteophytes and tissue swelling. Bouchard’s nodes develop in PIP.

choices.text: Both superior and inferior epigastric artery

questions.text: During a laproscopic surgery while inserting a lateral trocar for surgery which of the following is most prone to injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Both superior and inferior epigastric artery

The most common source of bleeding during laparoscopic surgery is through both superior and inferior epigastric arteries.

questions.text: Hesselbach’s triangle is bounded by the following, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Transversus abdominis muscle

Indirect inguinal hernia comes out of abdominal cavity through deep inguinal ring, travel inguinal canal and becomes superficial through superficial inguinal ring. Direct inguinal hernia enters inguinal canal through medial half of weak posterior wall (Hesselbach’s triangle) and becomes superficial through superficial inguinal ring.

questions.text: A 25 year old female came to the hospital after fighting with her husband. She reports that she is unable to speak. However, all neurological and physical examinations are normal, and she does not seem concerned about her condition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

La-belle indifference

La-belle indifference is seen in conversion disorder. It is the absence of concern towards one’s problem despite the apparent severe disability.

questions.text: A 34 year old female presents with abdominal pain. USG reveals multiple gall stones with no wall thickening. CBD diameter is 12 mm and serum bilirubin was 0.8. Alkaline phosphatase is 380 and GGT is raised by 5 times. What is the next best step of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

MRCP

In this clinical scenario, a patient with gallstones, a dilated common bile duct, and an elevated alkaline phosphatase level raises suspicion for common bile duct stones. The next best step would be to perform magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) to confirm their presence.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the psychiatric OPD with complaints that he misidentifies stranger’s as a single persecutor wearing different disguises. What is this syndrome called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fregoli syndrome

The man in the question is mistaking strangers as a familiar person/persecutor. He is under the delusion that the familiar person/stranger can assume the appearance of (or disguise themselves as) multiple strangers. This is known as Fregoli syndrome.

choices.text: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle
Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.text: The most common site of branchial cyst is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

The most common site of a branchial cyst is at the junction of the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle at its anterior border.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the ER following a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient opens his eyes to a painful stimulus, speaks inappropriately, and withdraws his limbs to a painful stimulus. What is his GCS score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

E2V3M4

The GCS score of this patient: E2V3M4

He opens his eyes to a painful stimulus – E2

He produces inappropriate words only – V3

He withdraws his limbs – M4

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy developed sudden pain and tenderness over his left hip following a minor fall. There is restricted abduction and internal rotation. He is a known case of hypothyroidism and high BMI. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

SCFE

The most likely diagnosis is slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). Adolescent age group, hypothyroidism, obesity, sudden onset of pain after trauma with restricted abduction, internal rotation are suggestive of SCFE.

choices.text: Once weekly over a period of 3 months
Twice weekly over a period of 3 months
Three times weekly over a period of 3 months

questions.text: A patient with a normal body mass index presents with episodes of binge eating followed by inappropriate compensatory actions. According to the DSM-5, these behaviors must happen, on average, at least:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Once weekly over a period of 3 months

For a diagnosis of bulimia nervosa, the binge-eating episodes and compensatory behaviors need to occur at least once a week for a minimum duration of three months.

questions.text: A woman presented with a BIRADS-5 breast lesion. Which of the following is a good prognostic factor for this lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ER positive

ER positivity is a good prognostic factor in breast cancer. The ER and PR are two steroid hormone receptors present in breast cancer. The expression of these receptors indicates a favorable prognosis and response to hormonal therapy.

questions.text: Using the X-ray given below. Identify the type of Salter & Harris classification:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The X-ray findings are consistent with a Type 2 Salter-Harris fracture, which is a type of growth plate fracture. A type II Salter-Harris fracture is the most common pediatric physeal fracture, occurring frequently in children over 10 years of age. This fracture breaks at an angle, cutting through most of the growth plate and the metaphysis, the area above the growth plate. The separated piece of the metaphysis is called a Thurston-Holland fragment.

choices.text: Do an urgent upper GI endoscopy
Put the patient in recovery position and secure airway
Insert a cannula and start IV fluids

questions.text: A 45 years old patient presented to you with ongoing massive hematemesis. The patient is alert and hemodynamically stable. What will be the first step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Put the patient in recovery position and secure airway  

As a part of the BLS algorithm, we should start with the airway management in any patient who is collapsed/expected to collapse. Since the patient is hemodynamically stable, the airway is the most important component at risk in this patient and requires immediate attention. The patient should be put in a recovery position i.e. left lateral decubitus position to prevent the risk of aspiration.

questions.text: eFAST is least helpful in diagnosing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Retroperitoneal hematoma

Among the given options, FAST (focussed assessment with sonography in trauma) is least useful in diagnosing retroperitoneal hematoma as the sensitivity of ultrasound for the detection of retroperitoneal hematomas is extremely poor.

questions.text: When a ‘spontaneous perforation’ of the esophagus occurs as a result of severe barotrauma while a person vomits against a closed glottis, the condition is known as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Boerhaave’s syndrome

Boerhaave syndrome is also known as spontaneous esophageal rupture or effort rupture of the esophagus. Although vomiting is thought to be the most common cause, other causes include those that can increase intra-esophageal pressure and cause a barogenic esophageal rupture.

choices.text: Stop aspirin to minimize perioperative bleeding risk
Stop metoprolol to increase cardiac output
Increase aspirin dosage for additional analgesic benefit

questions.text: A patient scheduled for elective hip surgery in 5 days is taking aspirin, a multivitamin, enalapril, and metoprolol. What is the appropriate perioperative management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Stop enalapril

In the given clinical scenario, where a patient is scheduled for elective hip surgery in 5 days and is taking aspirin, a multivitamin, enalapril, and metoprolol, the recommended perioperative management includes discontinuing enalapril, as it is an ACE inhibitor.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after suffering a stab injury to the lower chest. On presentation, he had bradycardia and hypotension which did not improve despite IV fluid administration. Chest radiography showed clear lung fields. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

eFAST

The next step in the management of this patient is to perform an eFAST. Persistent hypotension despite initial fluid resuscitation indicates an ongoing haemorrhage. It is mostly fatal if not controlled, and the source of haemorrhage must be identified by eFAST, chest and pelvic radiographs.

questions.text: As per DSM-5, which of the following is not classified under dissociative disorders?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Conversion disorder

As per DSM-5, conversion disorder (functional neurological symptom disorder) is classified under somatic symptom and related disorders, and not under dissociative disorders.

questions.text: A 70 year old female presents with extracapsular neck of femur fracture. What is the best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Dynamic hip screw

Intertrochanteric fractures are the most common type of extracapsular fracture. Dynamic hip screw is the managament for undisplaced intertrochanteric fractures.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male was diagnosed with achalasia cardia. High-resolution manometry revealed massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractions of the distal oesophagus. According to the Chicago classification, the patient has which type of achalasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The given features are suggestive of type III achalasia cardia. Type III achalasia cardia is characterised by massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractions of the distal esophagus.

choices.text: Percentage of burns x weight (kg) x 2 = volume in mL
Percentage of burnsx weight (kg)/2 = volume in mL
Percentage of burns x weight (kg) x 4 = volume in mL
Weight + 1500 ml/m2xBSA burnt = volume in mL

questions.text: A 26 year old woman, weighing 58 kg, has second-degree burns covering 20% of the total body surface area. Which of the following formulae would you use to calculate the amount of fluid to be given?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Percentage of burns x weight (kg) x 2 = volume in mL

According to the latest ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) 10th edition 2018, resuscitation formula for second and third-degree thermal burns in the first 24 hours is given by:

Total percentage body surface area burned weight (kg) x 2 = volume (mL).

questions.text: The most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is an insulinoma.The investigation of choice for insulinoma is the determination of 72-hour fasting glucose and serum insulin levels.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic met with a vehicular accident. His blood alcohol level is >300 mg/dl. He needs hospitalization and will be withheld from taking alcohol. The drug that will be used to manage his withdrawal symptoms is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Lorazepam

The first-line drug used in the management of this patient’s withdrawal symptoms is intravenous(IV) lorazepam.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male was posted for open inguinal hernia repair. He is a known hypertensive for the past 6 years and is poorly controlled on medications. Which of the following muscle relaxant can exacerbate hypertension in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Pancuronium

Pancuronium can exacerbate hypertension in poorly controlled patients by inducing vagal blockade and neural release of catecholamine leading to sympathetic stimulation.

questions.text: A patient presents following a motorcycle road traffic accident. There was no pain or injury. Examination shows blood at the tip of the urethral meatus. What will be your next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a suspected urethral injury since there is blood at the urethral meatus. The next best step in the management is a suprapubic cystostomy

questions.text: For infants and children under the age of 2, which of the following samples are the best to diagnose UTI?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Suprapubic aspiration and urethral catheterization

For infants and children under age 2, suprapubic aspiration and urethral catheterization are the preferred methods due to their high reliability and minimal contamination risk.

questions.text: Which of the following esophageal carcinomas is most likely to develop in patients with long-standing achalasia cardia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Squamous cell carcinoma

The most common type of carcinoma associated with this condition is squamous cell carcinoma. Achalasia is a premalignant condition. It becomes malignant due to long-standing, retained, undigested fermenting food in the body of the esophagus, causing mucosal irritation. Adenocarcinoma may also arise in the setting of achalasia but is less common as compared to SCC.

questions.text: Most common complication of ileostomy is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Skin irritation 

MC complication of ileostomy: Skin irritation

MC early complication of ileostomy: Ischemic necrosis

questions.text: An 18 year old male presented to your OPD with pain and swelling over the right knee following a traumatic injury. Aspiration of the joint revealed hemarthrosis. Injury to which of the following structures would not have led to this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Medial collateral ligament

Medial collateral ligament injury does not lead to hemarthrosis, as it is an extra-articular structure. The cruciate ligaments and menisci are intra-articular structures and hence their injury leads to hemarthroses.

questions.text: Which of the following should be the treatment of choice for renal cell carcinoma with tumor less than 4 cm in size?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Partial nephrectomy (also known as nephron-sparing surgery) is performed for tumors less than 4 cm in size.

questions.text: A patient has multiple blood clots in the urine following a TURP procedure. Which catheter should be used for irrigation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

22 French Foley’s 3-Way catheter

22 French Foley’s 3-Way Catheter is the most appropriate choice for this patient with blood clots after a TURP procedure.

questions.text: A spontaneously breathing 6 year old child is set to undergo a minor elective procedure. Which of the following circuits would be the best choice for ventilating this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Jackson Rees circuit

Jackson Rees modification of Ayre’s T piece is the circuit of choice for ventilating a spontaneously breathing child during anesthesia.

choices.text: Junction between 2nd and 3rd part of duodenum

questions.text: In a burn patient, the doctor is looking for curling ulcer. Which part should be examined?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1st part of duodenum Cushing ulcer: Stress gastritis due to intracranial injury/increased ICP Curling ulcer: After burn injury (> 35%); in the body and fundus; (not in antrum) and duodenum Cameron ulcers or riding ulcers: Linear gastric erosions in hiatal hernias

questions.text: Which of the following is not an intravenous induction agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Halothane

Halothane is an inhalational agent which is a halogenated alkane. Induction with halothane is relatively slow due to its high blood: gas partition coefficient (2.5).

questions.text: ASEPSIS wound scoring takes all of the following into consideration except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

ASEPSIS wound score does not take induration into consideration. Instead, the I in ASEPSIS stands for isolation of bacteria from the wound.

questions.text: At what age should the congenital defect (shown in the image below) be ideally repaired?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

3-6 months

The given image shows a unilateral cleft lip. Repair of cleft lip (primary palate) along with associated nasal deformities is done at 3-6 months of age.

questions.text: Identify the part marked ‘A’?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Edge

The edge of an ulcer is is represented by ‘A’. An ulcer is defined as a break in the continuity of the epithelium or mucous membrane with molecular death

questions.text: Which of the following congenital heart disease has equal saturation in all the chambers of the heart?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation

In total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation (TAPVC), there is equal saturation in all chambers of the heart.

questions.text: The results of semen analysis of a young male have been given below. What is the diagnosis? 5 million/ml concentration, 50% motility, 4% normal morphology
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Oligospermia

The given scenario of decreased sperm concentration with normal range of motility and morphology points to the diagnosis of oligospermia. Oligospermia is defined as sperm concentration of <15 million/ml.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman, postmenopausal for the past 5 years, presents with a complaint of intermittent episodes of vaginal bleeding over the last month. Pelvic ultrasound reveals an endometrial thickness of 6 mm. What is the most appropriate investigation for evaluating postmenopausal bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

In a postmenopausal woman presenting with postmenopausal bleeding, with an endometrial thickness of 6 mm on ultrasound, the most appropriate investigation is an endometrial biopsy. It is the most definitive method to diagnose endometrial hyperplasia, polyps, or cancer in postmenopausal women with bleeding and increased endometrial thickness.

questions.text: Which of the following ligaments supports the uterus by anchoring it laterally to the pelvic wall?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Mackenrodt's ligament (also known as the cardinal ligament ) is crucial for providing lateral support to the uterus and pelvic organs. It extends from the cervix and lateral fornices of the vagina to the pelvic sidewalls (parietal fascia of the obturator internus and piriformis muscles, the front edge of the greater sciatic foramen, and the ischial spines).

questions.text: Which Müllerian anomaly is shown in the image below
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: A 1-day-old neonate presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. An abdominal X-ray is performed and is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Jejunal atresia is characterized by a "triple bubble" sign on an abdominal X-ray. This appearance results from gas trapped in three distended proximal bowel loops: the stomach, duodenum, and proximal jejunum , with no distal gas beyond the atresia. This condition is caused by intrauterine vascular insult leading to segmental bowel absence or occlusion.

questions.text: According to the two-cell two-gonadotropin theory, which hormone stimulates the conversion of androgens to estrogens in granulosa cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

FSH

According to the Two-cell Two-Gonadotropin Theory:

The ovary has Theca cells (receptors for LH) and Granulosa cells (receptors for FSH).

LH stimulates Theca cells to produce androgens.

FSH stimulates Granulosa cells to convert androgens into estrogens via aromatase.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl was brought by her mother to the outpatient department with primary amenorrhea. She had normal breast development and pubic hair. On examination, the vagina was blind-ending and the uterus was not palpable. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mullerian agenesis

The given clinical scenario of a girl with primary amenorrhea, normal breasts, and pubic hair, with a blind-ending vagina and uterus not palpable, is suggestive of Mullerian agenesis.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely regarding Rh incompatibility in a newborn?
questions.solution:
